name: Georgette Heyer's Regency England Quiz | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: What is the odd one out?
questions.explanation:
Cotillion.

	Phaeton, barouche and curricle are types of carriage: cotillion is a dance.

questions.text: What would someone be doing to be accused of 'doing it far too brown'?
questions.explanation:
Telling a lie.

	Presumably refers to overdoing the (false) explanation

Overcoat.

	It is a plain overcoat worn for travelling.

questions.text: What is the odd one out?
questions.explanation:
Sarcenet.

	Basset, pharo and loo are all gambling games. Sarcenet is a dress fabric.

questions.text: What would you do at Almacks?
questions.explanation:
Dance.

	Almacks was a very correct society dance venue for matchmaking mamas.

questions.text: What would you buy from a mantua maker?
questions.explanation:
Ladies' clothes.

	Ladies' {clothes;} a mantua is a type of gown.

questions.text: What do you do if you 'fork' someone?
questions.explanation:
Pick their pocket.

	Forking someone is to pick their pocket. Pocket watches, snuff boxes and seals were all vulnerable.

questions.text: What is referred to as 'parson's mousetrap'?
questions.explanation:
Marriage.

	A disparaging nickname from young bachelors.

questions.text: What would you do with orgeat?
questions.explanation:
Drink it.

	Drink it - it is a soft drink, like barley water, suitable for young ladies

questions.text: Why would you go to Melton Mowbray?
questions.explanation:
To hunt.

	To hunt: Melton Mowbray was a favoured base for riding to hounds.
